bibl.title: Wah Ni v. State of Washington. Petition
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: IN THE CIRCUIT COUTY OF THE UNITED STATES, FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, WESTERN Northern DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of Wah Ni for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Comes now the above named petitioner Wah Ni, and for his pe- tition and complaint in writing for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, on oath respectfully shows to this court:

That on or about the 11th day of January, A.D., 1892, he left the City of Portland, Oregon, where he has resided for ten years immediately prior to said time, and had been for six years last past engaged in the merchantile business, for Hong Kong, Chi- na, and that he did, prior to taking his said departure, appear before one J. E. Marks, a Notary Public, and then and there sub- scribe and make the certificate hereunto attached and marked as exhibit "A" and making and forming a part of this his said peti- tion.

2. That all the facts and circumstances as set forth in said statement are true; that petitioner had, for six years last past, been actively engaged as a Chinese merchant in Portland, Oregon, and was at said time doing business at 254 Morrison Street and was a member of the firm of Yee Wah & Co., and as a member of said firm still having and retaining all of his said interests in said business, which was the sum of $1,000, and still having and re- ceiving his share of the profits from said business and was at said time a bona fide owner and holder of a one-tenth interest in said business, the capital stock of said business being $10,000, your petitioner being one of the junior partners in said business; and your petitioner fully and completely relied upon said J. E. Marks as an attorney at law for the proper wording and mak- ing of said certificate, and fully believes that the same fully

completely complies with the law as in such cases made and provided; that the said certificate is attached a photograph of your petitioner, which photograph petitioner had taken for the purpose of having same attached to said certificate.; and petition- er further states that at said time he did obtain the statement of persons well and favorable known to him, one of said persons be- ing Capt. Thomas Hawks, who was for a number of years a policeman upon the beat upon which petitioner's business was located and frequently met the said Hawks, and that afterwards said Thomas Hawks was deputy tax collector in the city of Portland and had called upon this petitioner and collected taxes, and that the said Capt. Thomas Hawks did sign said statement attached to said cer- tificate, and that he is the same Thomas Hawks whose affidavit is hereunto attached, and that the said certificate of petitiner is a correct copy of petitioner's certificate with the exception of the photograph and attached hereto and marked as exhibit "A" as aforesaid.

Your petitioner further states that he did, on or about the 11th day of January, 1892, take his departure for Hong Kong, Chi- na, anndt and did there remain and visit with his parents, rela- tives and friends, and transact his business and the business of his said firm, which was that of viewing, examining and ascertain- ing the prices of goods and making arrangements for the buying and shipping from the manufacturers in China; that thereafter, he did, about the 10th day of January, 1893, take passage on the steamer Victoria at Hong Kong, China, to return to the United States of America, and that he did pay his farer said passage and did re- turn to and was landed at the steamboat wharf at Tacoma, and did then and there present his certificate and request to be landed; that one Plummer, representing himself to be a deputy collector, did, without any cause, right, or authority, and without explain-

ing or making known to this petitioner any of his reasons for not allowing him to land, refuse to allow your petitioner to land, al- though your petitioner had in all ways and manner complied with the laws of the United States of America, and did offer and was willing to produce the witnesses who signed said statement to said certificate, together with other witnesses both white and Chinese who knew and would identify him your petitioner as having resided in the city of Portland for a number of years last past, and as being a good, honest, upright and bona fide merchant in said city and a member of the firm doing buisness at 254 Morrison street, in the city of Portland, Oregon, but regardless of said of- fer, said Plummer made to your petitioner or to one Moy Yuck who well understands and speaks the English language, no satisfactory explanation whatsoever, and gave him no reason whatsoever for re- fusing to admit your petitioner, but did take from your petitioner his certificate with his photograph thereto attached, and the statement as thereto attached signed by the petitioner and re- speciive parties as set forth in exhibit "A", and did refuse to re- turn same to your petitioner and has ever since said tine retained same and does still continue to retain same, and your petitioner has not had or seen the same since said time, and the same is still had and retained by said Plummer or the Collector of Customs or some one under him, without the consent and against the wish and protest of petitioner, and petitioner further states that on the evening of the 8th day of May, 1893 about the hour of 5 o'clock, he was informed that the said steamer Victoria, with a large num- ber of Chinese passengers, aobut two hundred in number, nearly all of whom were strangers to this petitioner, and of whome he knew nothing, and had no relation,would, at 4 o'clock on the morning of the 9th inst. loose from the wharf at Tacoma, and be cleared

for and return upon her return trip to Hong Kong; and that your petitioner, together with his two companions, who are likewise merchants and who likewise ask for a writ of abeas corpus, would be forcibly, unjustly, unlawfully and illegally and without any cause whatsoever, and without being informed as to cause, com- pelled to remain upon said vessel and htus be compelled to return to Hong Kong. That your petitioner did cause to be made, diligently search and inquiry to find and ascertain the whereabouts of this Honorable Court to apply to it for a writ of habeas corpus, and did apply in Absence of the Court to the Commissioner of your Honorable Court for said writ, which was refused by said Commissioner for the reason that he had no authority to issue said writ, and that your petitioner was then compelled to resort to and did apply to the Superior Court of Pierce Count, washington, for a writ of habeas corpus, setting forth the facts and circumstances, which application was consider- ed by the Court and by said Court, the Honorable W. H. Pritchard who granted, said writ in the words following to-wit: "Let the writ of habeas corpus and the warrant issue as prayed for in the within complaint and petition. May 8, 1893. W. H. Pritchard, Judge." That the said W. H. Pritchard was, at that time one of the duly elected and qualified and acting jusges of the Superior Court of the state of washington, for the County of Pierce, said cause being number 9688 as appears by the record and files of said Superior Court of the State of Washington, for the county of Pierce; and that thereupon the clerk of said court did, under the seal of said court, issue said writ of habeas corpus and warrant fo for the arrest of said wah Ni as prayed for in said petition, and under said writ the sheriff did proceed to the steamboat wharf and to the steamer Victoria, and ask for the said Wah Ni, who was called for by the captain of said steamer, and without any fur- ther orders and without any protest, ordered the said Wah Ni to go ashore, which said wah Ni did then and thereupon do, without any protest or resistance or proceedings of any kind of any rep-

resentative whatsoever of the United States of America; and that the said captain did thereafter appear before the said Superior Court and make and file his written answer to said writ of habeas corpus, and that then and thereupon, and upon the filing of said answer, the said petitioner Wah Ni, by his counsel demurred there to, which demurrer was by the court sistained andafter hearing the respective counsel and arguments of same, the said Wah Ni was then and thereupon by said court, in the presence of the oficers of the government discharged by the said Superior Court which he was be- fore, all of which proceedings, including the said petition, or- der of said court, writ of habeas corpus, warrant of arrest and return of the officers upon it andsaid process, answer of the said captain, the ruling and order of the court and record of the pro- ceedings of the respective parties, appears of the record in the rec- ords of the Superior Court of the State of Washington for the County of Pierce in cause number 9688 as given, made and filed therein.

That immediately upon the discharge of said Wah Ni as afore- said he was then and thereupon arrested charged with being ille- gally in the United States of America, and was taken before Honor- able Miles K. Clifford, Court Commissioner of theCircuit Court of the United States at Tacoma, who proceeded to inquire into said cause, and did refuse to allow said petitioner to be turned over to the United States marshall to be returned to said steamer Vic- toria. which was still at the wharf at Tacoma and ordered that said petitioner be held and returned by the United States marshall for a hearing before him, which hearing was fixed for the 17th day of May, 1893 at 10 o'clock in the forenoon, at which hearing evi- dence was take introduced for the the respective parties and your said petitioner was by said Commissioner ordered deported, from which or- der, judgment and ruling, with the consent of the United States attorney waiving all forms and regularities of giving notice, an

appeal was taken to this Honorable Court, and upon the question of jurisdiction of the United States Commissioner being, by the United States attorney raised, this Honorable Court did, on the 5th day of June, 1893, order that your said petitioner be turned over to and placed in custody of the United States marshal, J. C. Drake, who proceeded and took your said petitioner into possession, and now forcibly, knowingly, unlawfully, without just cause is now holding, detaining and retaining and keeping in confinement your said petitioner, although he has demanded his liberty, re- fused to recognize said demands, and still continues to hold, re- tain, detain and deprive this petitioner of his liberty, and your petitioner states that he can, if allowed a hearing before this Honorable Court, show that he has fully and completely complied with all the laws of the United States and the ruels and regula- tions thereof, and regardless of said compliance, the Collector of Customs did wilfully, knowingly, arbitrarily, unjustly and un- lawfully, and withou any cause, right or authority, refuse to ad- mit your said petitioner and allow him to land, and that your said petitioner is rightfully and justly entitled to land and be and re- main in the United States of America, and go his way to his former residence as heretofore stated and resume his business at the city of Portland, Oregon.

Your petitioner further states that he is at this time impris- oned at the United States penitentiary at McNeill's Island, in Pierce County, Washington, and within the jurisdiction of this court; that he is not detained by virtue of any order or process issued by the United States Court, nor by virtue of any execution or any other process, judgment, decree or final order of any state court or any other court other than herein stated as aforesaid; and that he is not held for the violation of any law, rule or regula- tion or in punishment for any crime by him committed other than herein stated.

Petitioner further states that he is advised by Marshall K. Snell, his counsel, who resides at Tacoma, Pierce County, wash- ington, and who is a counselor of this court, having and holding a certificate authorizing him to practice in and before this court, that such imprisonment is illegal for the reason and facts as herein set forth, 'and that under and by virtue of the laws of the United States, a writ of habeas corpus directed to the said United States Marshal should be issued by this Honorable Court to bring before it your petitioner.

WHEREFORE, your petitioner ever prays and hereby applies for a Writ of Habeas Corpus for the purpose of an inquiry into the cause of such imprisonment and restraint, and delivering him there- from and discharging him from custody.
